Message.Title: Microsoft's Windows 8 turning off PC buyers
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: "Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 8 was supposed to spark an increase in personal computer sales. Instead, the PC industry is poised to contract for the second year in a row. And Windows 8 actually could be hurting PC sales. "Market research firm IDC this week slashed its 2013 PC shipment forecast. It now expects worldwide PC shipments to decline 1.3% this year over 2012, when PC shipments fell 3.7%. IDC had previously expected PC sales to rise 2.8%, but the predicted bump from Windows 8 didn't materialize. "IDC blamed the PC shipment declines on competition from tablets, especially Apple's (AAPL) iPad, and a continuing economic malaise that has crimped IT budgets. "Far from being the cure for sluggish PC sales, Windows 8 has turned out to be part of the problem."

Message.Title: Microsoft Takes Over #6 Spot From General Electric
Message.Msg: Google it... The headline is oddly worded. It would be more accurate to say GE took over the #5 spot from Microsoft. Microsoft has been declining in rank in recent months. The ranking is on the basis of market capitalization.

Message.Title: Uptake gap between Windows 8 and Vista widens even as new OS gains share
Message.Msg: W8 is garbage....an increase of 0.6% is GOOD news????? ========================================= Computerworld - Windows 8 last month fell even further behind the historical adoption pace of Windows Vista, Microsoft's 2007 flop, new statistics showed today. The bright spot for Windows 8 in the data from Web analytics company Net Applications: Its share of all Windows PCs increased in March by a larger margin than the month before, reversing a trend of declining growth since the OS launched in October. According to Net Applications, Windows 8's March usage share -- including what the firm labeled as "touch" for Windows 8 and Windows RT -- was 3.6% of all Windows PCs, up from February's 3%. Windows 8's share increase in March was six-tenths of a percentage point, larger than February's gain of five-tenths of a point. From November -- the first full month after Windows 8's launch -- through February, the operating system's increases had grown smaller each month. =============================================
